{{Infobox Software | name = Partimage | logo = | screenshot = [[Image:Partimage.png|300px]] | caption = Partimage 0.6.7 on Ubuntu | collapsible = | author = Francois Dupoux and Franck Ladurelle | developer = | released = | released = {{Start date|2001|09|11}} | discontinued = | latest release version = 0.6.9 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2010|07|25}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = {{Start date and age|2009|09|29}} | frequently updated = | programming language = | operating system = [[Linux]], [[Cross-platform]] ([[Live CD]]) | platform = | size = | language = | status = | genre = | license = [[GNU General Public License]] | website = http://www.partimage.org/ }} '''Partimage''' is a [[disk cloning]] utility for [[Linux]]/[[UNIX]] environments. Partimage can save [[disk partitioning|partitions]] in many formats to a [[disk image]]. Utilities such as Partimage are useful in a number of situations which are commonly encountered by network administrators as well as advanced computer users who maintain their own systems.
== Common Uses == Some common uses for Partimage are as follows.<ref>[http://www.debianadmin.com/backup-and-restore-linux-partitions-using-partimage.html Backup and Restore Linux Partitions Using Partimage - Debian Admin<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Backup]] of individual disk partitions. [[Volume (computing)|volume]] backups are very useful for recovery in the case of a disk failure or data corruption. * Large-scale operating system deployment. Organizations with multiple, similar computer systems may use Partimage or similar utilities to ease the process of [[operating system]] and [[software]] [[provisioning]].
== Features == For [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] users, Partimage includes experimental support for [[NTFS]]. Partimage supports most common Linux [[file systems]], and can be found in many [[Linux distribution]]s, including [[Debian]]<ref>[http://packages.debian.org/unstable/admin/partimage Debian Partimage]</ref> and the [[Live Distro]]s PING,<ref>[http://ping.windowsdream.com/ping/download.html PING Partimage]</ref> [[Knoppix]]<ref>[http://www.kernel.org/pub/dist/knoppix/packages.txt Knoppix Partimage]</ref> and [[SystemRescueCD]].<ref>[http://www.sysresccd.org/Detailed-packages-list SystemRescueCD Partimage]</ref>
Other notable features include [[data compression|compression]] of disk image files, support for backup/restore from a network file server and data [[encryption]].
Partimage uses [[Newt (programming library)|Newt]] for its GUI.
Partimage is limited to cloning partitions that have supported filesystem types. This includes [[Ext2]], [[Ext3]], [[Reiserfs]], [[Fat16]], [[Fat32]], [[HPFS]], [[JFS (file system)|JFS]], [[Xfs]], [[Unix file system|UFS]], [[Hierarchical File System|HFS]] and [[Ntfs]]. Partimage does NOT support [[Ext4]] which is the default on new Ubuntu installations.
